Catalytic amination of diethylene glycol with tert‑butylamine to tertiarybutylaminoethoxyethanol over NiCu/Al2O3 catalysts: Facilitation of NiCu alloy Xiaozhong Wang Writing – review & editing Resources a b Jiali Hu Investigation Formal analysis Writing – original draft a b Cai Xu Writing – review & editing Resources a b ⁎ Yingqi Chen Resources Writing – review & editing a b Liyan Dai Supervision Resources Writing – review & editing a b ⁎ a Zhejiang Provincial Key Laboratory of Advanced Chemical Engineering Manufacture Technology, College of Chemical and Biological Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou 310027, PR China Zhejiang Provincial Key Laboratory of Advanced Chemical Engineering Manufacture Technology College of Chemical and Biological Engineering Zhejiang University Hangzhou 310027 PR China aZhejiang Provincial Key Laboratory of Advanced Chemical Engineering Manufacture Technology, College of Chemical and Biological Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou 310027, PR China b Institute of Zhejiang University - Quzhou, Quzhou 324000, PR China Institute of Zhejiang University - Quzhou Quzhou 324000 PR China bInstitute of Zhejiang University, Quzhou 324000, PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors at: Zhejiang Provincial Key Laboratory of Advanced Chemical Engineering Manufacture Technology, College of Chemical and Biological Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou 310027, PR China. Zhejiang Provincial Key Laboratory of Advanced Chemical Engineering Manufacture Technology College of Chemical and Biological Engineering Zhejiang University Hangzhou 310027 PR China Herein, a series of NiCu/Al2O3 catalysts were prepared by impregnation method and subsequent thermal treatment under different reduction temperatures. The catalysts exhibited excellent catalytic activity for the amination of diethylene glycol (DEG), and satisfactory yield of tertiarybutylaminoethoxyethanol (TBEE) could be obtained. XRD, N2 adsorption-desorption, SEM, TEM, XPS, and H2-TPR were employed to characterize the catalysts, the interaction between Ni and Cu on the catalytic activity was studied. It was found that NiCu alloy was formed after catalyst reduction, which strengthened the reduction ability of NiO and increased the number of Ni0 active center, contributing to the enhanced catalytic activity. Moreover, the effects of reaction parameters on catalytic activity were explored. There was no need for a solvent, only 3 molar equivalents of tert‑butylamine (TBA) and 1 wt.% catalyst was required. After 7 h of reaction at 220 °C, satisfactory conversion (89.6%) and selectivity (84.6%) were obtained over the prepared catalyst. Cycle experiment demonstrated that the prepared catalyst retained excellent stability and reusability after six runs without significant loss of catalytic activity. This work provided an efficient catalyst for the catalytic amination of diethylene glycol with tert‑butylamine to TBEE. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Reduction temperature NiCu alloy Facilitation Tertiarybutylaminoethoxyethanol Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Amines are derivatives formed by the substitution of hydrogen atoms in ammonia by hydrocarbon groups, which have been widely applied in the chemical industry. Tertiarybutylaminoethoxyethanol (TBEE) is a representative sterically hindered amine, the (CH3)3CNH- group in its structure promises it a steric effect when reacting with CO2, while H2S can still be excellently reacted with, so as to achieve the purpose of selective removal of H2S [1]. TBA and 2-chloroethoxyethanol are used as raw materials in the industrial synthesis process of TBEE, and there are several issues with the above production process, including reactor corrosion (haloalkane by-products), high production costs (complex purification operation), and serious environmental issues (large quantity of inorganic chlorides) [2]. With the continuous evolution of green chemistry, an eco-friendly route for the production of TBEE is urgently needed. In recent years, amination of alcohols has emerged as an effective and worthwhile method of amine synthesis. DEG is a by-product of ethylene oxide hydration to produce ethylene glycol. TBEE can be produced by using DEG and TBA as raw materials with the help of catalyst, and the main by-products are N-tertiarybutyl-morpholine (TBM) and water, which satisfies the demand for green and high-quality industrial development [3]. To date, the active metals in alcohol amination reactions have been reported to be Ru [4–6], Pd [7,8], Ir [9,10], and Au [11–13]. For instance, Fang et al. discovered that, 5 wt.% Ru/HBEA (Si/Al = 25) provided over 90% conversion and 90% selectivity to 1-octylamine in the liquid-phase amination reaction of 1-octanol with ammonia at 180 °C in a batch reactor [4]. Salarinejad et al. synthesized a nanotube catalyst Pd/Fe3O4@NC, under exogenous base and solvent-free conditions, it demonstrated high conversion (99%) and turnover frequency (3.96 h −1) in the one-pot synthesis of imine and secondary amine from benzyl alcohol [7]. Some researchers have attempted to develop non-noble metals, but the catalytic activity was not satisfactory [14,15]. More recently, alloy catalysts have attracted increasing attention in the field due to their powerful synergistic impact between two pure metals [16]. For example, Yuan et al. prepared Ni-Co alloy catalysts (Ni1Co2@NC-APTES) and applied them in the hydrogenation of nitrocyclohexane to cyclohexanone oxime, the alloy effects between Ni and Co highly promoted catalytic activity, achieving 94.5% conversion and 93.6% selectivity [17]. Lin et al. employed hydrotalcite-derived Ni-Ga alloy catalysts for methane decomposition, alloying improved the resistance of metal catalysts against sintering and effectively enhanced catalyst life and carbon yield [18]. Wang et al. synthesized Cu-Co/C alloy catalysts with excellent catalytic activity and stability in low-temperature steam reforming of toluene and biomass tar, carbon deposition and the change of catalyst structure after reaction were inhibited by alloying [19]. In general, the alloying method can be used to change the electronic properties, reducibility, and dispersion of metal catalysts as well as catalytic properties [20–22]. Similarly, the use of an alloying strategy in the amination reaction of alcohol is expected to improve the catalytic activity. To the best of our knowledge, up to now, there are few investigations on the use of alloy catalysts in the amination reaction of DEG. NiCu bimetallic catalysts were frequently utilized in hydrogen-mediated reactions, such as the selective hydrogenation of unsaturated aldehydes [23], CO hydrogenation [24], ethanol steam reforming [25], etc. and the results were generally satisfactory. Inspired by the previous reports, we selected Ni and Cu as active components for research. In this work, we reported the catalytic amination of DEG to TBEE over NiCu/Al2O3 catalysts. It was found that the catalyst with a reduction temperature of 600 °C had the best catalytic activity. Thus, a variety of characterizations (including XRD, N2 adsorption-desorption, SEM, TEM, XPS, and H2-TPR) were employed to determine the relationship between the structure of catalyst and amination activity. Moreover, the effects of reaction parameters (such as H2 pressure, reaction temperature, reaction time, stirring speed, TBA: DEG molar ratio, and catalyst amount) on catalytic activity were explored as well. Finally, a possible reaction mechanism for the catalytic amination of DEG to TBEE was proposed. This work lays the groundwork for further developing industrial catalysts with superior performance. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Nickel acetate tetrahydrate (Ni(OAc)2∙4H2O), copper acetate monohydrate (Cu(OAc)2∙H2O), aluminum oxide (99.99% metals basis, powder) and diethylene glycol (＞98%) were provided by Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd (China). Tert-butylamine (98%) were purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd (China). Ethanol and ethyl acetate were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd (China). All of chemicals listed above were analytical grade and could be used without further purification. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Impregnation method was used to prepare a series of NiCu/Al2O3 catalysts. All catalysts were given the same Ni content of 20% and Cu content of 5%. Typically, 0.851 g of Ni(OAc)2∙4H2O and 0.157 g of Cu(OAc)2∙H2O were dissolved in 50 mL of deionized water, and then 1 g of Al2O3 was added after vigorous stirring for 30 min. After two-hour impregnation treatment, the water in the mixture was evaporated at 90 °C. Solid sample was then collected and dried overnight at 100 °C before being calcined at 550 °C for 5 h with a ramping rate of 3 °C min−1 in a muffle furnace. Finally, the solid product was reduced for 3 h in a temperature-programmed tubular furnace with 10% H2/Ar at a designated temperature (400, 500, 600, and 700 °C). For convenience, the obtained catalysts were denoted as NiCu/Al2O3–400, NiCu/Al2O3–500, NiCu/Al2O3–600 and NiCu/Al2O3–700, respectively. 2.3 General X-ray diffraction (XRD, Rigaku Ultima IV, Japan) was used to study the crystal structure of samples through Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.15418 nm). N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were collected by Micromerics Tristar II 3020 analyzer at −196 °C after samples were degassed in vacuum at 200 °C for 8 h, specific surface area of samples was calculated by BET method, and pore size distribution was obtained by BJH method. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Zeiss Sigma 300, Germany) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, FEI Tecnai G2 F30, USA) equipped with an energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) were used to investigate the morphology and microstructure of catalysts. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Scientific K-Alpha, USA, Al Kα radiation, 1486.6 eV) was used to study the chemical composition and valence states of catalysts and obtained data were calibrated by using contaminated carbon at C 1s=284.6 eV. Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 analyzer with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) was used to perform H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR). The operation conditions were as follows: 40 mg of catalyst was placed in a U-quartz tube and pretreated with helium flow at 180 °C for 30 min, and then the samples were heated from 50 to 800 °C with a ramping rate of 10 °C min−1 in a 10% H2/Ar flow (30 mL min−1). 2.4 Activity tests Catalytic amination of DEG was performed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. In a typical experiment, 0.848 g of DEG, 1.752 g of TBA, and 0.026 g reduced catalyst were added into reactor. After sealing, purged with H2 for three times and then filled with H2 to 0.5 MPa. Magnetic stirring speed was 600 rpm, and temperature was kept at 220 °C for 7 h. Reaction mixture was cooled to room temperature after reaction. catalyst was filtered, and liquid phase products were collected. the recovered solid catalyst was washed with ethanol thoroughly before being dried overnight in an oven at 100 °C for reuse. Gas chromatography (GC, Fuli 9790II) was used to analyze the filtrate diluted with ethyl acetate, which was connected to a PB-50 capillary column (30 m × 0.32 mm × 0.33 μm) and a flame ionization detector (FID). The retention time of standard samples in the GC diagram was used to determine the products. External standard method was used to calculate DEG conversion and TBEE selectivity. Equations were as follows: Conversion of DEG ( % ) = converted DEG in molar initial DEG in molar × 100 Selectivity of TBEE ( % ) = generated TBEE in molar converted DEG in molar × 100 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization The XRD patterns of catalysts after reduction at various kinds of temperatures were shown in Fig. 1 . All catalysts held γ-Al2O3 diffraction peaks at 2θ = 37.7, 45.9, and 66.9° (PDF #77–0396). Characteristic diffraction peaks of metal Ni and Cu (111), (200), and (220) planes were close, and located at 2θ = 44.5, 51.9, and 76.4° (PDF #04–0850) and 2θ = 43.3, 50.4, and 74.1° (PDF #04–0836), respectively. As reported by literature, diffraction peaks at 2θ = 44.3, 51.6, and 75.8° belonged to NiCu alloy phase (Ni-rich) [26,27]. The formation of NiCu alloy promoted the release and reduction of Ni in mixed oxides [28]. It could also improve the interaction between Ni and Cu components, thereby upgrading the adsorption performance of bimetallic catalysts for reactant molecules [29]. According to the figure, intensity of NiCu alloy diffraction peaks of NiCu/Al2O3–400, NiCu/Al2O3–500, and NiCu/Al2O3–600 catalysts gradually increased, and each peak was wide, indicating good dispersion. When reduction temperature raised to 700 °C, diffraction peak pattern of NiCu/Al2O3–700 catalyst at 2θ = 44.3° turned sharp, suggesting that grain size is large and crystallinity is high, which might block the pore structure of carrier material, causing a decrease in catalytic activity [30]. In addition, all catalysts exhibited type IV isotherms and obvious H4 hysteresis loops (Fig. 2 ), indicating that the prepared catalysts had typical mesoporous structure [31,32]. Table 1 showed specific surface area, pore volume, and pore size of samples. With reduction temperature raised, specific surface area decreased continuously, pore size increased, and pore volume first increased and then decreased, which proved that Ni and Cu could fill and cover the surface and internal pores of Al2O3 carrier effectively. The specific surface area decreased rapidly at an excessively high reduction temperature (700 °C), as metal particles on the surface of Al2O3 carrier were overly aggregated at this time, obstructing some pores [33,34], which was consistent with the XRD results. The NiCu/Al2O3–600 catalyst possessed the largest pore volume, which allowed for full exposure of active components, promoting reactant molecule diffusion and product molecule migration [35]. SEM was performed to examine the morphology of catalysts. Fig. S1. suggested that impregnation method prepared irregular spherical stacked catalysts, and the surface morphology changed slightly as reduction temperature raised. TEM provided further morphology information. In Fig. 3 a–d, black particles could be seen, illustrating that metal components had been successfully dispersed on the Al2O3 carrier [36]. Through comparison found that the NiCu/Al2O3–600 catalyst had a better dispersion effect and smaller particles. Fig. 3e and f were element mappings obtained by STEM-EDS, showing the overlapping spatial distribution of Ni and Cu, demonstrating that Cu was integrated into Ni lattice, forming NiCu alloy particles [37]. As shown in Fig. 3g, HRTEM image displayed lattice fringes with interplanar spacings, corresponding to (111) plane of NiCu alloy. HADDF-STEM line scanning was carried out at randomly chosen area (Fig. 3h), and it was discovered that the composition profile of Ni and Cu was essentially the same, proving formation of NiCu alloy structure again [31]. XPS analysis was used to investigate the chemical and electronic states of elements on the surface of catalysts. The XPS survey confirmed the presence of elements Cu, Ni, O and Al in the sample, as shown in Fig. 4 a, and the corresponding element content could be obtained from Table 2 . As illustrated in Fig. 4b and c, O 1 s owned a single characteristic peak with a binding energy of 531.2 eV, whereas the main peak of Al 2p with a binding energy of 74.5 eV, which corresponded to O and Al in the Al2O3 lattice, respectively [38]. The Ni 2p orbit and Cu 2p orbit, as displayed in Fig. 4d and e, split into two peaks due to spin coupling, corresponding to Ni 2p1/2, Ni 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2, Cu 2p3/2, respectively. Two comparatively strong fitting peaks in Fig. 4d, centered at 873.7 eV (Ni 2p1/2) and 856.0 eV (Ni 2p3/2) belonged to Ni2+, while two comparatively weak fitting peaks, centered at 870.7 eV (Ni 2p1/2) and 853.3 eV (Ni 2p3/2) were indexed to Ni0. A mixed state of Ni2+ and Ni0 was represented by these peaks. Satellite peaks could also be found near 879.5 and 862.0 eV [39]. Ni0 had been demonstrated to be the active site in this reaction [40], and the figure showed that Ni0 peak intensity in the NiCu/Al2O3–600 catalyst was the highest. Peaks with centers of 956.2 eV (Cu 2p1/2) and 934.8 eV (Cu 2p3/2) in Fig. 4e were associated with Cu2+, while peaks with centers of 952.4 eV (Cu 2p1/2) and 932.5 eV (Cu 2p3/2) were assigned to Cu0 or Cu+. This demonstrated that CuO remained on the surface of catalysts [41,42], and main peak of Cu+ overlapped with Cu, it is difficult to distinguish. Consequently, AES analysis of Cu LMM spectra was used. Three binding energy peaks near 575.6, 571.1, and 568.0 eV in the Cu LMM spectra (Fig. 4f) corresponded to Cu+, Cu2+ and Cu0 states, indicating that there were three Cu valence states on the catalyst surface [43,44]. It was notable that Cu0 of Cu 2p3/2 in the sample migrated towards a higher binding energy, while Ni0 binding energy of Ni 2p3/2 declined [33]. This shift phenomenon could be attributed to alteration in the distribution of electrons between Ni and Cu brought on by the formation of NiCu alloy. And the charge transfer from Cu to Ni increased the electronic density of Ni, which could prevent the occurrence of side reactions [36]. H2-TPR was performed to explain the reducibility of catalysts and the interaction between metal and carrier (Fig. 5 ). Reduction behavior was further demonstrated by the reduced catalysts, as shown in the figure, but in comparison to literature, the consumption of H2 was lower, and hydrogen consumption peaks appeared to shift to low temperatures during reduction process [30]. Because Al2O3 couldn't be reduced within the research temperature scope, reduction depicted was the reduction of various Cu and Ni species. Below 300 °C, all catalysts held two reduction peaks. The lower temperature peak was attributed to the reduction of highly dispersed CuO on Al2O3, whereas the higher temperature peak stood for the reduction of bulk CuO particles [45]. As reduction temperature raised, reduction of CuO transferred to high temperature, and surface dispersed Cu increased. Higher Cu dispersion could reduce Cu particle agglomeration, enhancing catalyst durability [46]. Reduction peak of NiCu/Al2O3–400 at 524 °C was attributed to the reduction of NiO strongly interacting with the carrier [47]. This broad peak indicated the presence of a mixture of NiOx species [48]. It was visible that rising temperatures could promote NiO reduction, and there was no NiO reduction peak in NiCu/Al2O3–500 and NiCu/Al2O3–600, pointing out that Ni species reduction was adequate at this time. The relatively weak peak (330 °C) in NiCu/Al2O3–700 was thought to be free NiO particles [36], indicating that reduction temperature of 700 °C was too high, impeding Ni reduction in the catalyst. In summary, increasing reduction temperature was beneficial, and 600 °C was proven to be optimal. 3.2 Catalytic activity of the prepared catalysts To investigate the effect of catalysts, catalytic amination of DEG to TBEE was used as a probe reaction. Fig. 6 depicted the catalytic performance of an unreduced NiCu/Al2O3 catalyst and catalysts reduced at different temperatures. DEG conversion was low when an unreduced catalyst acted on the reaction, indicating that catalyst reduction was critical to the reaction. DEG conversion was greatly increased after catalyst reduction. Furthermore, NiCu/Al2O3–600 catalyst demonstrated excellent selectivity, and when NiCu/Al2O3–400 or NiCu/Al2O3–500 acted on the reaction, a large number of by-products were formed. The increase in selectivity could promote the increase in target product yield. For this reason, TBEE yield of NiCu/Al2O3–600 was the highest, at 75.8%, roughly 1.4 times that of NiCu/Al2O3–500 and 1.1 times that of NiCu/Al2O3–700, demonstrating the importance of catalyst reduction temperature. Appropriate reduction temperature was conducive to the formation of NiCu alloy, which increased the dispersion of active components on the surface of carrier, and promoted the exposure of active site to improve the catalytic activity. The effects of H2 pressure, reaction temperature, reaction time, stirring speed, TBA: DEG molar ratio, and catalyst amount on catalytic activity were studied as well. DEG and TBA reacted for 7 h at 220 °C with NiCu/Al2O3–600 as a catalyst, and reaction results with different H2 pressure were shown in Fig. 7 a. The result reflected that without H2, DEG conversion was low. According to the reaction mechanism, H2 was not necessary for the catalytic amination of alcohols; however, H2 played a significant role in this reaction, it could effectively prevent the catalyst deactivation caused by the formation of metal carbides and metal nitrides during the reaction [49,50]. As a result, the reaction should be carried out in the presence of H2. As H2 pressure increased, DEG conversion increased, whereas TBEE selectivity increased initially and then decreased. When H2 pressure was high, some by-products were generated. Thus, optimal H2 pressure for this reaction was 0.5 MPa. Besides, experimental results in Fig. 7b showed that reaction temperature had a significant influence on the amination of DEG. DEG conversion reached maximum at 220 °C, whereas TBEE selectivity decreased rapidly after exceeding 240 °C. This demonstrated that higher reaction temperatures contributed to the occurrence of side reactions. The effect of reaction time on the catalytic activity of amination of DEG was displayed in Fig. 7c. After 7 h of reaction, the conversion of DEG reached 89.6%. With further extension of reaction time, no obvious increase of DEG conversion was observed. We considered that the reason was the generation of water during the reaction. Since the amination of DEG with TBA was a dehydration reaction, the generation of water impeded the complete conversion of DEG. To verify this deduction, a control experiment was carried out. A small amount of water (1 mL) was added to the reactor, it was found that the conversion of DEG was decreased to 5.6%, demonstrating that water would impede the conversion of DEG. On the other hand, Excessive reaction time would conversely result in a slight decrease of selectivity to TBEE. Contact degree of reactants and catalyst was greatly influenced by stirring speed, and best performance was obtained when rotating speed was set to 600 rpm (Fig. 7d). The effect of TBA dosage on catalytic activity was shown in Fig. 7e. The boiling point of TBA was relatively low (46 °C), and there would be some TBA loss inevitably during the gas displacement process. Therefore, in order to ensure better conversion effect of DEG, TBA must be excessive. Moreover, TBA existed in a gaseous form during the reaction process, and adding too much TBA could significantly increase the pressure of the reaction system. Excessive pressure could lead to the generation of a large number of by-products, which was quite detrimental to the selectivity of target product. Overall, the yield of TBEE was the highest when 3 molar equivalents of TBA were added, so 3 molar equivalents were preferred in this reaction. Moreover, we explored catalyst amount in a similar way and plotted it in Fig. 7f. DEG conversion increased when the catalyst amount was increased, but was not significantly promoted by further increase (>26 mg), whereas TBEE selectivity decreased. Overall, the prepared catalyst exhibited beneficial catalytic activity for the amination of DEG to TBEE under certain reaction conditions (fill 0.5 MPa H2, reacting at 220 °C for 7 h, stirring speed of 600 rpm, 3 molarequivalents of TBA, 26 mg catalyst). 3.3 General applicability We used different types of alcohols as substrates to expand the reaction on the NiCu/Al2O3–600 catalyst to verify the general applicability of the catalytic system (Table 3 ). As could be observed, ethylene glycol (entry 2) and n-heptanol (entry 3) had superior conversion and selectivity than the original substrate DEG. The amination of aromatic alcohols (entries 4 and 7) could also be effectively carried out, with extremely high conversion. However, 4-methoxybenzyl alcohol (entry 7) had a much lower selectivity than benzyl alcohol (entry 4), which could result from the negative inductive effect's reduction in the electron cloud density on aromatic rings [51]. When 2-(hydroxymethyl) pyridine (entry 5) and 3-methyl-2-buten-1-ol (entry 6) were used as substrates, it was found that their catalytic efficiency was moderate. Overall, the prepared NiCu/Al2O3 catalyst was applicable for the amination of various alcohols with TBA, which probably provided some new ideas for the design of non-noble metal catalyst for amination reactions. 3.4 Catalyst reusability Cyclic experiments were carried out under optimal reaction conditions, recoverability and stability of the NiCu/Al2O3–600 catalyst was discussed. After each run, solid catalyst was separated by simple filtration, thoroughly washed with ethanol, and dried in an oven at 100 °C overnight for reuse. The results (Fig. 8 a) showed that after six consecutive operations, DEG conversion remained at 82% and TBEE selectivity remained at 84%. As could be seen from the figure, conversion and selectivity of reaction did not significantly decrease during recycling, demonstrating that there was no apparent loss of catalytic activity, confirming its reusability and stability, which was enhanced by the formation of NiCu alloy. Further, XRD and SEM tests were performed on the catalyst to see if the morphology and structure had changed after six cycles. The figures illustrated that the surface morphology of catalyst did not change after six cycles (Fig. 8c and d), and its crystal morphology remained essentially unchanged (Fig. 8b). This demonstrated that metal grain size of catalyst had not changed significantly after multiple reactions, indicating that catalyst was stable. 3.5 Proposed reaction mechanism According to previous reports, the catalytic amination process of alcohol is divided into three stages: alcohols are dehydrogenated by metal catalysts into corresponding carbonyl compounds, carbonyl compounds react with amines to form intermediate imines, and then reduced by metal catalysts with hydrogen previously taken away from alcohols to obtain new amines, which is referred to as the "borrowing hydrogen mechanism" [52–54]. We come up hypothesis the mechanism (Scheme 1 ) based on the results above, DEG contacts and interacts with NiCu alloy particles that are loaded on the surface of Al2O3 to dehydrogenate DEG and form more active carbonyl compounds, similar to the common reductive amination mechanism. It can dehydrate and condense with TBA at the acidic site on the surface of Al2O3 [55,56], resulting in the synthesis of an intermediate imine. The formation of target product TBEE is caused by the hydrogenation of imines and the "borrowed" hydrogen from the starting alcohol. NiCu alloy-Al2O3 interface provides a higher active site for this step. Furthermore, the alkaline site on Al2O3 is thought to be beneficial in inhibiting TBEE from further dehydration to form the by-product TBM, allowing for high TBEE selectivity [57]. 4 Conclusion To summarize, NiCu alloy was formed among the prepared NiCu/Al2O3 catalysts during the reduction process. It was found that Ni and Cu had strong interactions, which improved the catalytic activity. Besides, the catalysts were significantly affected by reduction temperatures. After reduction at 600 °C, the catalyst had the greatest amount of Ni0, providing enough active sites for the amination reaction of DEG, and therefore the NiCu/Al2O3–600 catalyst had the highest catalytic activity. Under the optimum reaction conditions, conversion of DEG and selectivity to TBEE were 89.6% and 84.6% respectively after 7 h of reaction at 220 °C. The catalyst could be easily recovered and no obvious loss of activity was observed after 6 cycles, indicating excellent reusability. This work demonstrates that NiCu/Al2O3 catalysts with low cost and high efficiency has great application prospects in the field of amination catalysis. coredata.dc:description: Herein, a series of NiCu/Al2O3 catalysts were prepared by impregnation method and subsequent thermal treatment under different reduction temperatures. The catalysts exhibited excellent catalytic activity for the amination of diethylene glycol (DEG), and satisfactory yield of tertiarybutylaminoethoxyethanol (TBEE) could be obtained. XRD, N2 adsorption-desorption, SEM, TEM, XPS, and H2-TPR were employed to characterize the catalysts, the interaction between Ni and Cu on the catalytic activity was studied. It was found that NiCu alloy was formed after catalyst reduction, which strengthened the reduction ability of NiO and increased the number of Ni0 active center, contributing to the enhanced catalytic activity. Moreover, the effects of reaction parameters on catalytic activity were explored. There was no need for a solvent, only 3 molar equivalents of tert‑butylamine (TBA) and 1 wt.% catalyst was required. After 7 h of reaction at 220 °C, satisfactory conversion (89.6%) and selectivity (84.6%) were obtained over the prepared catalyst. Cycle experiment demonstrated that the prepared catalyst retained excellent stability and reusability after six runs without significant loss of catalytic activity. This work provided an efficient catalyst for the catalytic amination of diethylene glycol with tert‑butylamine to TBEE.
coredata.dc:title: Catalytic amination of diethylene glycol with tert‑butylamine to tertiarybutylaminoethoxyethanol over NiCu/Al2O3 catalysts: Facilitation of NiCu alloy
